Authors: Aarna I., Suuberg E.M.
Title: A study of the reaction order of the NO-carbon gasification reaction
Affiliations: Division of Engineering, Brown University, Providence, RI 02912, United States
Authors with affiliations: Aarna, I., Division of Engineering, Brown University, Providence, RI 02912, United States; Suuberg, E.M., Division of Engineering, Brown University, Providence, RI 02912, United States
Abstract: The heterogeneous reduction of NO with carbon can be an important process in destruction of NO in combustion systems. In this study, apparent reaction orders of NO reduction by graphite, resin char, and Wyodak coal char were investigated at different temperatures and pressures in the kinetic control regime. The results indicate that reaction orders increase from zero to unity as temperature increases. In the lowtemperature regime, reaction rate is determined by a desorption process, which is a very weak function of NO pressure; in the high-temperature regime, direct NO attack, a first-order reaction, determines the overall rate. The behavior at intermediate temperatures is determined by the sum of two processes. This resolves a long-standing discrepancy between the claim that the process is desorption controlled at low temperatures and reports of apparent first order. There is evidence of very long timescale dynamics associated with rearrangement of surface oxides at low temperatures, which can significantly affect the observed rates and therefore observed apparent reaction orders. Previously reported first-order kinetics with cleaned samples at low temperatures reflect complicated transient rather than steady-state behavior. The determination of correct apparent reaction order in fixed-bed reactors is complicated by the long times needed to reach true steady state and by the possibility of surface-catalyzed reaction of NO with product CO.
Index Keywords: Coal gasification; Desorption; Nitrogen oxides; Pressure effects; Rate constants; Thermal effects; Reaction order; Wyodak coal char; Coal combustion

Authors: Abdelatif G., Emam H.
Title: Investigation of plasma properties produced by laser irradiated Al target
Source title: IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science
Affiliations: Cairo Univ, Cairo, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Abdelatif, G., Cairo Univ, Cairo, Egypt; Emam, H., Cairo Univ, Cairo, Egypt
Abstract: Diagnostics of the plasma produced by laser irradiated Al target was carried out at wavelengths 1064, 532, and 355 nm. The spatial distribution of the electron temperature for the three laser wavelengths followed almost the same behavior with a peak which varies its position depending on both the laser wavelength and energy. The values of these peaks varied from 1.6 to 6 ev. The same behavior was observed at wavelengths 100, 40, and 40 mJ in both the ultraviolet and visible region with peak positions shifting slightly away from the target. No spectral emission was observed with infrared wavelength when the energy was reduced to a value below 400 mJ. A spatial profile of the electron density was determined using a Stark broadening formula.
Index Keywords: Aluminum; Carrier concentration; Laser beams; Light absorption; Light emission; Neodymium lasers; Plasma diagnostics; Q switched lasers; Boltzmann plots; Electron freezing zones; Electron temperature; Stark broadening equation; Laser produced plasmas

Authors: Abdelouas A., Lu Y., Lutze W., Nuttall H.E.
Title: Reduction of U(VI) to U(IV) by indigenous bacteria in contaminated ground water
Affiliations: Advanced Materials Laboratory, University of New Mexico, Ctr. for Radioactive Waste Mgmt., 1001 University Blvd., Albuquerque, NM 87106, United States; University of New Mexico, Dept. of Chem. and Nucl. Engineering, Albuquerque, NM 87131, United States
Authors with affiliations: Abdelouas, A., Advanced Materials Laboratory, University of New Mexico, Ctr. for Radioactive Waste Mgmt., 1001 University Blvd., Albuquerque, NM 87106, United States; Lu, Y., Advanced Materials Laboratory, University of New Mexico, Ctr. for Radioactive Waste Mgmt., 1001 University Blvd., Albuquerque, NM 87106, United States; Lutze, W., University of New Mexico, Dept. of Chem. and Nucl. Engineering, Albuquerque, NM 87131, United States; Nuttall, H.E., University of New Mexico, Dept. of Chem. and Nucl. Engineering, Albuquerque, NM 87131, United States
Abstract: We report on bio-catalyzed reduction and immobilization of U(VI) species (0.25 mg/l to 235 mg/l) in ground water in the presence of high concentrations of nitrate, sulfate and carbonate. We studied ground water from the uranium mill tailings site near Tuba City, Arizona (USA). Experiments with the ground water were conducted in the presence of the Navajo sandstone host rock. Uranium in solution is complexed by carbonate. Two indigenous denitrifying bacteria were identified Pseudomonas aeruginosa and P. stutzeri, and one sulfate reducing bacterium, Shewanella putrefaciens, also known as Fe(III)-reducer. S. putrefaciens can use U(VI) as an electron acceptor, instead of Fe(III). Ethanol was used as the organic carbon source. Microbially mediated reactions are sequential in the order of decreasing redox intensity. Metabolic reduction of nitrate to gaseous species (N2, N2O) was complete within 1 week at 16°C. The sulfate concentration remained constant. Some of the U(VI) coprecipitated with aragonite/calcite or was adsorbed on biomass during denitrification. Subsequently, the enzymatically catalyzed reduction of U(VI) to U(IV) was complete within 3 weeks but was accompanied by reduction of sulfate to sulfide. U(IV) precipitated as a uraninite solid solution (U, Ca)O2, adhering to the bacteria. The final concentration in solution was ≤1 μg/l. U(VI) was not reduced by sulfide. Complexation of U(VI) by carbonate made its reduction by sulfide even slower than in pure water. The bio-catalyzed reaction is the faster process under the conditions given by the composition of the ground water. Copyright (C) 1998 Elsevier Science B.V.The bio-catalyzed reduction and immobilization of U(VI) species in groundwater in the presence of high concentrations of nitrate, sulfate, and carbonate were studied. The microbially mediated reactions were sequential in the order of decreasing redox intensity. Metabolic reduction of nitrate to gaseous species (N2, N2O) was completed within 1 week at 16 °C. The enzymatically catalyzed reduction of U(VI) to U(IV) was completed within 3 weeks but was accompanied by reduction of sulfate to sulfide.
Author Keywords: Biosorption; Calcite; Coprecipitation; Denitrification; Ground water; Navajo sandstone; Speciation; Uraninite; Uranium bioremediation

Authors: Aboulnaga M.M.
Title: A roof solar chimney assisted by cooling cavity for natural ventilation in buildings in hot arid climates:An energy conservation approach in Al-ain city
Affiliations: Dept. of Architectural Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, UAE University, P. O. Box 17555, Al-Ain, United Arab Emirates
Authors with affiliations: Aboulnaga, M.M., Dept. of Architectural Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, UAE University, P. O. Box 17555, Al-Ain, United Arab Emirates
Abstract: The paper presents a parameteric analytical study of roof solar chimney coupled with wind cooled cavity using spread-sheet computer program. Detailed description and sizing of such system are presented. Separation between the external leaf and solar chimney's external glazing is optimized. The proposed roof solar chimney alone is able to create an air flow rate up to 1.6 kg/s at a mean incident solar radiation of 850W/m2. The maximum air velocity derived in the chimney is about 1.1m/s. At an average incident solar radiation 575W/m2, and air velocity in the chimney of 0.9m/s, the average mass flow rate is found as 1.3 kg/s. For a wind speed of 4.0 m/s the cooled cavity can create a mass flow of 0.35 kg/s. The system may be applied to more than one storey building. It is however, useful to be incorporated with a stand-alone building or with a cluster of buildings. © 1998 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Energy conservation; Hot-Arid climates; Natural ventilation; Passive cooling systems; Solar chimney; UAE

R. and D. Auth., Albany, NY 12223, United States
Abstract: Biomass-for-bioenergy cropping and production systems based on willow (and poplar) planted and managed at high densities and short (3-4 year) coppice harvest cycles, providing fuel for co-firing with Coal (or other types of energy conversion) must be ecologically and environmentally sustainable to be commercially successful. Current knowledge arid ongoing research and development indicate that the production and utilization systems involved are environmentally and ecologically sustainable. Therefore two primary constraints to commercialization are being met. The remaining constraint is economic viability based on cost of production and use, the value of environmental externalities (such as atmospheric emissions), and potential government/public policy actions to promote this system of providing a locally produced and renewable farm Crop and fuel. The environmental and ecological benefits of the system should act as a catalyst for developments needed to overcome the economic constraints of the system.Biomass-for-bioenergy cropping and production systems based on willow (and poplar) planted and managed at high densities and short (3-4 year) coppice harvest cycles, providing fuel for co-firing with coal (or other types of energy conversion) must be ecologically and environmentally sustainable to be commercially successful. Current knowledge and ongoing research and development indicate that the production and utilization systems involved are environmentally and ecologically sustainable. Therefore two primary constraints to commercialization are being met. The remaining constraint is economic viability based on cost of production and use, the value of environmental externalities (such as atmospheric emissions), and potential government/public policy actions to promote this system of providing a locally produced and renewable farm crop and fuel. The environmental and ecological benefits of the system should act as a catalyst for developments needed to overcome the economic constraints of the system.

Authors: Acker K., Möller D., Marquardt W., Brüggemann E., Wieprecht W., Auel R., Kalaß D.
Title: Atmospheric research program for studying changing emission patterns after German unification
Affiliations: Brandenburg Tech. University Cottbus, Working Group Air Chemistry, Rudower Chaussee 5, D-12484 Berlin, Germany; Institute for Tropospheric Research, Permoserstraße 15, D-04303 Leipzig, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Acker, K., Brandenburg Tech. University Cottbus, Working Group Air Chemistry, Rudower Chaussee 5, D-12484 Berlin, Germany; Möller, D., Brandenburg Tech. University Cottbus, Working Group Air Chemistry, Rudower Chaussee 5, D-12484 Berlin, Germany; Marquardt, W., Institute for Tropospheric Research, Permoserstraße 15, D-04303 Leipzig, Germany; Brüggemann, E., Institute for Tropospheric Research, Permoserstraße 15, D-04303 Leipzig, Germany; Wieprecht, W., Brandenburg Tech. University Cottbus, Working Group Air Chemistry, Rudower Chaussee 5, D-12484 Berlin, Germany; Auel, R., Brandenburg Tech. University Cottbus, Working Group Air Chemistry, Rudower Chaussee 5, D-12484 Berlin, Germany; Kalaß, D., Brandenburg Tech. University Cottbus, Working Group Air Chemistry, Rudower Chaussee 5, D-12484 Berlin, Germany
Abstract: A dramatic decrease in emission of sulphur dioxide (SO2, 60%), dust (82%), nitrogen oxide (NO, 30%) and other pollutants (hydrochloric acid (HCl); ammonia (NH3)) has been observed in East Germany after German unification in 1989. The smaller decrease in total NO is due to significant increase of NO from traffic. Air-pollutant concentrations in both parts of Germany before and after 1989 will be compared and their development will be discussed, based on precipitation and cloud chemistry data from long-term continuous record. Sectoral rain data, based on backward trajectory calculations, clearly show that the significant decline in annual volume weighted precipitation ions (sulphate, calcium, ammonium, chloride) in rain water from sector 'East' since 1989 and particularly since about 1992 is roughly correlated with a similar percentage decline in SO2, dust and NH3 emissions for the region East Germany. The acidity of the precipitation from sector 'East' has increased very strikingly from 1993 up to 1995 threefold more than from sector 'West'. Despite the strong decrease in SO2 emission, this decrease of the atmospheric neutralising capacity was caused by the much steeper decline in atmospheric base cations in that region. Precipitation data from all transport directions show high variation, but no significant trend in the annual average H+ ion concentration. At Mt. Brocken the annual average volume weighted cloud-water acidity during frost-free periods increased by a factor of three between 1992 and 1995. This result, confirmed also by the annual frequency distributions of the pH values, reflects the atmospheric pollutant loading also from all entry sectors. After 1995 this trend is reversed. Detailed classification of the cloud-water data by entry sector, and by meteorological and especially microphysical factors is currently being carried out and preliminary results are presented.
Author Keywords: Cloud chemistry; Emission; Precipitation chemistry; Trend

Authors: Ackerman M.C., Jefferson C.M.
Title: Global emissions due to urban transport and the potential for their reduction
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Urban Transport and the Environment for the 21st Century
Affiliations: Univ of the West of England, Bristol, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Ackerman, M.C., Univ of the West of England, Bristol, United Kingdom; Jefferson, C.M., Univ of the West of England, Bristol, United Kingdom
Abstract: The worldwide growth in the volume of transport is giving rise to increasing concern over the consequent increase in emissions. The rise in CO2 emissions is hindering the drive to minimize the `Greenhouse Effect' and other more noxious emissions are causing a deterioration in urban air quality. Urban transport is estimated to account for over 20% of total CO2 emissions in the USA, of which up to 50% is due to energy wasted in braking. The figure worldwide could well be approaching this. Assuming that 60% of this energy is recoverable through regenerative braking, it is possible that total global CO2 emissions could be reduced by 4% by implementation of currently available brake energy recovery technologies. The reduction in other emissions could be far more significant due to the optimized engine management systems which such technologies allow. This paper describes brake energy recovery technologies, and their introduction so far, in comparison with other measures such as use of alternative fuels.
Index Keywords: Air pollution control; Air quality; Braking; Carbon dioxide; Gas emissions; Greenhouse effect; Internal combustion engines; Urban planning; Brake energy recovery technologies; Engine management systems; Motor transportation

Title: A free electron laser-photoemission electron microscope system (FEL-PEEM)
Affiliations: Department of Physics, NCSU, Raleigh, NC 27695, United States; Department of Engineering, NCSU, Raleigh, NC 27695, United States; FEL Laboratory, Department of Physics, Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ade, H., Department of Physics, NCSU, Raleigh, NC 27695, United States; Yang, W., Department of Physics, NCSU, Raleigh, NC 27695, United States; English, S.L., Department of Engineering, NCSU, Raleigh, NC 27695, United States; Hartman, J., Department of Engineering, NCSU, Raleigh, NC 27695, United States; Davis, R.F., Department of Engineering, NCSU, Raleigh, NC 27695, United States; Nemanich, R.J., Department of Physics, NCSU, Raleigh, NC 27695, United States; Litvinenko, V.N., FEL Laboratory, Department of Physics, Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, United States; Pinayev, I.V., FEL Laboratory, Department of Physics, Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, United States, FEL Laboratory, Department of Physics, Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, United States; Wu, Y., FEL Laboratory, Department of Physics, Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, United States; Madey, J.M.J., FEL Laboratory, Department of Physics, Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, United States; Litvinenko, V.N., FEL Laboratory, Department of Physics, Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, United States; Pinayev, I.V., FEL Laboratory, Department of Physics, Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, United States, FEL Laboratory, Department of Physics, Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, United States; Wu, Y., FEL Laboratory, Department of Physics, Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, United States; Madey, J.M.J., FEL Laboratory, Department of Physics, Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, United States
Abstract: We report first results from our effort to couple a high resolution photoemission electron microscope (PEEM) to the OK-4 ultraviolet free electron laser at Duke University (OK-4/Duke UV FEL). The OK-4/Duke UV PEL is a high intensity source of tunable monochromatic photons in the 3-10 eV energy range. This tunability is unique and allows us to operate near the photoemission threshold of any samples and thus maximize sample contrast while keeping chromatic aberrations in the PEEM minimal. We have recorded first Images from a variety of samples using spontaneous radiation from the OK-4/Duke UV PEL in the photon energy range of 4.0-6.5 eV. Due to different photothreshold emission from different sample areas, emission from these areas could be turned on (or off) selectively. We have also observed relative intensity reversal with changes in photon energy which are interpreted as density-of-state contrast. Usable image quality has been achieved, even though the output power of the FEL in spontaneous emission mode was several orders of magnitude lower than the anticipated full laser power. The PEEM has achieved a spatial resolution of 12 nm.

Authors: Adler K., Grant M., Schroeer W.
Title: Emissions reduction potential of the congestion mitigation and air quality improvement program: A preliminary assessment
Affiliations: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Off. of Plcy., Plan., and Evaluation, 401 M Street, S.W., Washington, DC 20460, United States; Apogee Research, Inc., 4350 East-West Highway, Bethesda, MD 20814, United States; Apogee Research, Inc., 2097 Jefferson Avenue, St. Paul, MN 55105, United States
Authors with affiliations: Adler, K., U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Off. of Plcy., Plan., and Evaluation, 401 M Street, S.W., Washington, DC 20460, United States; Grant, M., Apogee Research, Inc., 4350 East-West Highway, Bethesda, MD 20814, United States; Schroeer, W., Apogee Research, Inc., 2097 Jefferson Avenue, St. Paul, MN 55105, United States
Abstract: The Congestion Mitigation and Air Quality (CMAQ) program provides funds to states for projects designed to help attain the national ambient air quality standards. However, to date there has been no attempt to quantify the national emissions effects of the CMAQ program or its potential. States are requested to provide estimates of emissions reductions associated with projects funded by the CMAQ program to FHWA. These reports provide a rich source of data for analysis of the CMAQ program, although the data have various limitations. A methodology to estimate potential effects of the CMAQ program on emissions of volatile organic compounds, oxides of nitrogen, and carbon monoxide using data provided by the states to FHWA is presented. Using this methodology, a preliminary assessment of the emissions effect of the CMAQ program from its inception in 1992 through 2005 is presented. It is suggested that the CMAQ program is playing a significant role in reducing emissions nationwide. Emissions estimates are sensitive to assumptions about project costeffectiveness and years of effect. In addition, various limitations in the national database of CMAQ projects are noted. The use of consistent methodologies for estimating the effects of programs nationwide is recommended to improve the accuracy of national emission reduction estimates.
Index Keywords: Gas emissions; Standards; Traffic control; Transportation; Volatile organic compounds; Air quality improvement program; Congestion mitigation; Emissions reduction potential; Air quality

Abstract: The tensor analyzing power T20 of the reaction d + A → π (0°) + X has been measured in the fragmentation of 9 GeV tensor polarized deuterons into pions with momenta from 3.5 to 5.3 GeV/c on hydrogen, beryllium and carbon targets. This kinematic range corresponds to the region of cumulative hadron production with the cumulative variable xc from 1.08 to 1.76. The values of T20 have been found to be small and consistent with positive values. This contradicts the predictions based on a direct mechanism assuming NN collision between a high momentum nucleon in the deuteron and a target nucleon (NN → NNπ). © 1998 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Affek H.P., Ronen D., Yakir D.
Title: Production of CO2 in the capillary fringe of a deep phreatic aquifer
Affiliations: Dept. Environ. Sci. and Ener. Res., Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, Israel; Dept. Environ. Sci. and Ener. Res., Weizman Institute of Science, 76100 Rehovot, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Affek, H.P., Dept. Environ. Sci. and Ener. Res., Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, Israel, Dept. Environ. Sci. and Ener. Res., Weizman Institute of Science, 76100 Rehovot, Israel; Yakir, D., Dept. Environ. Sci. and Ener. Res., Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, Israel, Dept. Environ. Sci. and Ener. Res., Weizman Institute of Science, 76100 Rehovot, Israel
Abstract: CO2 profiles obtained along a 30-m-thick unsaturated zone under land irrigated with sewage effluents show two production regions: a seasonal one in the root zone and another, at steady state, near the water table (29 m). On an annual basis the CO2 flux from the deep source toward the atmosphere (6.3 g C m-2 yr-1) is balanced by a similar influx of soluble organic carbon (SOC) from sewage effluents. The δ13C values of soil CO2 indicate that CO2 is produced from plant material in the root zone and from biodegradation of total sedimentary organic carbon in the capillary fringe. High CO2 concentration in the capillary fringe (up to 2%) is likely to reflect a decrease in diffusivity relative to the unsaturated zone due to increase in both water content and tortuosity induced by the capillary fringe structure. The long residence time of SOC and CO2 in the unsaturated zone (29 years at the study site) suggests that the unsaturated zone of deep aquifers may have a significant storage capacity for carbon and may act as a temporary carbon sink.
Index Keywords: aquifer; carbon dioxide; aquifer; capillary fringe; carbon dioxide; sink; unsaturated zone; Aquifers; Biodegradation; Effluents; Groundwater; Hydrogeology; Organic carbon; Sewage; Capillary fringe; Plant material; Production of CO; Residence time; Sewage effluents; Steady state; Storage capacity; Unsaturated zone; Carbon dioxide

Abstract: Systematic results are presented on proton, deuteron, and triton emission from the target spectator region in collisions of [Formula Presented] GeV gold projectiles with a gold target. A forward hodoscope utilizes detection of projectile spectator fragments to determine the orientation of the reaction plane, event by event. The directed flow [Formula Presented] is determined as a function of pseudorapidity. Projectile spectator energy is used to estimate impact parameters. Results are compared to current theoretical models ARC, ART, and RQMD. In all cases good agreement with theory is obtained for calculations utilizing a pure cascade without nuclear potential contributions. © 1998 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Ahlén N., Johnsson M., Nygren M.
Title: Synthesis and characterisation of TaxTi1 xC and TaxTi1-xCyN1-y, whiskers
Source title: Journal of the European Ceramic Society
Affiliations: Department of Inorganic Chemistry, Stockholm University, S-106 91 Stockholm, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Ahlén, N., Department of Inorganic Chemistry, Stockholm University, S-106 91 Stockholm, Sweden; Johnsson, M., Department of Inorganic Chemistry, Stockholm University, S-106 91 Stockholm, Sweden; Nygren, M., Department of Inorganic Chemistry, Stockholm University, S-106 91 Stockholm, Sweden
Abstract: TaxTi1-xC and TaxTi1-xCyN1-y whiskers have been synthesized via a carbothermal vapour-liquid-solid (VLS) growth mechanism in the temperature region 1250-1400°C, in argon and nitrogen atmospheres, respectively. The starting materials consisted of Ta2O5, TiO2, C, Ni and NaCl. Carbon was added to reduce the oxides, and nickel to catalyse the whisker growth. NaCl was used as a source of Cl for vapour phase transportation of Ta-oxochlorides and Tichlorides to the catalyst. The yield of whiskers was about 80 vol%, with a length of 10-30μm and a diameter varying from about 0·25μm for TaC to about 0·55μm for TiC. The whiskers were straight and had smooth surfaces. TEM studies showed that they were monocrystalline. The average x-value of the formed whiskers could be controlled by varying the weighed-in ratio of Ta2O5 to TiO2 and the synthesis temperature. The maximum nitrogen content decreased with increasing x value in TaxTi1-xCyN1-y. The residual oxygen content in the whiskers decreased with increasing synthesis temperature and increasing x-value. © 1998 Elsevier Science Limited. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: fiber reinforced composite; strength; testing; whisker

Authors: Ahn S.H., Jeon D., Lee K.R., Kim J.M.
Title: Emission sites on diamond-like carbon films studied by scanning anode
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE International Vacuum Microelectronics Conference, IVMC
Affiliations: Myong Ji Univ, Seoul, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Ahn, S.H., Myong Ji Univ, Seoul, South Korea; Jeon, D., Myong Ji Univ, Seoul, South Korea; Lee, K.R., Myong Ji Univ, Seoul, South Korea; Kim, J.M., Myong Ji Univ, Seoul, South Korea
Abstract: We deposited diamond-like carbon (DLC) films using ion beam sputtering of carbon target on flat substrates for use as a thin film field emitter. N-type silicon, titanium-coated silicon, and indium tin oxide (ITO) -coated glasses were used as a substrate. Field emission measurement was performed in 3×10-7 Torr vacuum. The films hardly exhibited emission before a breakdown occurred at high voltage. To study the role of breakdown, we measured local emission by scanning the surface with a tip anode. The result showed that most emission was contributed from the sites melted and deformed by breakdown. Further analysis of the damaged sites were done by scanning Auger spectroscopy, micro Raman spectroscopy, and scanning-electric field microscopy. Formation of SiC and local field enhancement due to morphology change was confirmed from these measurements.
Index Keywords: Anodes; Auger electron spectroscopy; Electric breakdown of solids; Electron emission; Glass; Indium compounds; Ion beams; Morphology; Raman spectroscopy; Scanning electron microscopy; Silicon; Substrates; Diamond-like carbon films; Diamond films

Authors: Ahn Terry, Kogan Vladimir, Torres Edward
Title: Air toxics emissions from wastewater treatment plants - five years after the initial AB 2588 submittal
Source title: Proceedings of the Air & Waste Management Association's Annual Meeting & Exhibition
Affiliations: County Sanitation Districts of, Orange County, Fountain Valley, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ahn, Terry, County Sanitation Districts of, Orange County, Fountain Valley, United States; Kogan, Vladimir, County Sanitation Districts of, Orange County, Fountain Valley, United States; Torres, Edward, County Sanitation Districts of, Orange County, Fountain Valley, United States
Abstract: The California Air Toxics 'Hot Spots' Information and Assessment Act of 1987 (AB 2588) requires facilities to submit the Air Toxics Emissions Inventory Report (ATIR) and Health Risk Assessment (HRA) reports. County Sanitation Districts of Orange County (CSDOC) which operate two large wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs) in Southern California, prepared their original ATIR and HRA reports based on 1989-1990 emissions. Due to significant changes at both facilities, CSDOC was required to prepare and submit completely updated AB 2588 reports reflecting the 1995-96 toxic emissions. CSDOC used source testing as emissions quantification method. Additional source tests were conducted for different emission sources from 1992 to 1995. The results of these extensive source testing program allowed CSDOC to develop reliable emission factors (EFs) to estimate air toxic emissions from WWTPs.
Index Keywords: Ammonia; Combustion; Cost effectiveness; Estimation; Formaldehyde; Gas emissions; Health risks; Industrial plants; Mathematical models; Regulatory compliance; Toxicity; Wastewater treatment; Air toxic emission; Air toxic emission inventory report; County Sanitation Districts of Orange County; Health risk assessment report; Wastewater treatment plant; Air pollution control

Authors: Aksenov A.V., Belyakov V.A., Sadykova Z.G.
Title: Calculation of the emission of nitrogen oxides in electric resistance heating furnaces
Affiliations: Moscow Stt. Metall. Evening Inst., Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Aksenov, A.V., Moscow Stt. Metall. Evening Inst., Moscow, Russian Federation; Belyakov, V.A., Moscow Stt. Metall. Evening Inst., Moscow, Russian Federation; Sadykova, Z.G., Moscow Stt. Metall. Evening Inst., Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: The present paper is devoted to the least studied topic in the field of use of modern electric heating equipment, namely, pollution of the atmosphere by nitrogen oxides and reduction of the intensity of this effect by coating furnace linings. Experimental and theoretical estimates of reduction of the emission of nitrogen oxides in electric furnaces with a lining with an intensifying refractory coating of the IVA-2 and IVAKS-2 types and an algorithm for calculating the emission of nitrogen oxides are presented. The plotted process of metal heating in an electric furnace shows that the use of IVA-2 and IVAKS-2 refractory coatings decreases the emission of nitrogen oxides by 22-28% both in a still oxidizing medium and under forced feeding of air into the heating zone. A method for calculating the characteristics of the process of emission of nitrogen oxides in electric furnaces is suggested. Results of the work can be applied to heating and heat-treatment furnaces of forging and rolling mills, especially in enviromentally vulnerable regions.

Authors: Al-Abdalla A., Barandiarán Z., Seijo L., Lindh R.
Title: Ab initio model potential embedded-cluster study of the ground and lowest excited states of Cr3+ defects in the elpasolites Cs2NaYCl6 and Cs2NaYBr6
Affiliations: Departamento de Química, C-14, Univ. Autónoma de Madrid, 29049 Madrid, Spain; Chemical Center, University of Lund, Lund, 22100, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Al-Abdalla, A., Departamento de Química, C-14, Univ. Autónoma de Madrid, 29049 Madrid, Spain; Barandiarán, Z., Departamento de Química, C-14, Univ. Autónoma de Madrid, 29049 Madrid, Spain; Seijo, L., Departamento de Química, C-14, Univ. Autónoma de Madrid, 29049 Madrid, Spain; Lindh, R., Chemical Center, University of Lund, Lund, 22100, Sweden
Abstract: In this paper we present the results of an ab initio model potential (AIMP) embedded-cluster study of the ground and lowest excited states of Cr3+ defects in the elpasolites Cs2NaYCl6 and Cs2NaYBr6; complete active space SCF (CASSCF) and averaged coupled-pair functional (ACPF) calculations are performed on CrCl3-6 and CrBr3-6 cluster embedded in ab initio model potential representations of the surrounding lattices Cs2NaYCl6 and Cs2NaYBr6. The experimental structural data are revisited and some new results are found which differ significantly from those available in the literature. The calculated local structure parameters and electronic transition energies which can be compared to experiments are found to be very good; new structural and spectroscopic results are produced which have been neither measured nor calculated, which are complementary to the available ones, and whose quality is expected to be high as well. In particular, the question of the competition of the excited-state absorptions with the potential vibronic laser emission has been adressed: A considerable overlap between the broad 2 Eg →2 A1g excited-state absorption and 4 A2g ←4 T2g emission bands is predicted in both materials, which must result in a reduction in the emission efficiency. Finally, it is shown that the quantum mechanical embedding effects due to the fact that the external Cs+, Na+, Y3+, Cl-, and Br- ions are not point charges, are non-negligible; lacking of these effects must be one of the reasons which make previous Density Functional Theory calculations show significantly larger discrepancies with the available experiments. © 1998 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Alasfour F.N.
Title: NOX emission from a spark ignition engine using 30% iso-butanol-gasoline blend: Part 1 - Preheating inlet air
Affiliations: Mechanical Engineering, Kuwait University, P.O. Box 5969, Safat 13060, Kuwait
Authors with affiliations: Alasfour, F.N., Mechanical Engineering, Kuwait University, P.O. Box 5969, Safat 13060, Kuwait
Abstract: This research investigated the effect of using a 30% iso-butanol-gasoline blend on NOX emission in a spark ignition engine. The influence of preheating inlet air on NOX emission was also investigated at different fuel/air equivalence ratio. A single cylinder Hydra research engine was used, running at 1500 rpm over a wide range of fuel/air equivalence ratio (0.7-1.1). It was observed that by using the 30% iso-butanol-gasoline blend the maximum level of NOX emission is reduced by 9% compared to gasoline and the reduction of NOX level was evident in the rich region. The experimental investigations were performed under different values of inlet air temperatures. Preheating the inlet air above ambient temperature causes the NOX emission level to increase for all fuel/air equivalence ratios. At Φ = 0.90, a 10% increase in NOX was observed when the inlet air temperature increased from 40 to 60 C. For 30% iso-butanol-gasoline blend experimental results show that preheating inlet air causes knock and misfire 1.0 occur at less advanced ignition timing. © 1998 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Air preheating; Iso-butanol; NOx emission; Spark ignition engine
Index Keywords: Alcohol fuels; Combustion knock; Exhaust gases; Gas emissions; Gasoline; Intake systems; Nitrogen oxides; Air preheating; Isobutanol; Misfire; Internal combustion engines

Authors: Alcamo J., Swart R.
Title: Future trends of land-use emissions of major greenhouse gases
Source title: Mitigation and Adaptation Strategies for Global Change
Affiliations: Ctr. for Environ. Systems Research, University of Kassel, Germany; Natl. Inst. Pub. Hlth. the Environ., Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Alcamo, J., Ctr. for Environ. Systems Research, University of Kassel, Germany; Swart, R., Natl. Inst. Pub. Hlth. the Environ., Netherlands
Abstract: Land-use emissions of greenhouse gases make up over one-third of current total anthropogenic emissions of greenhouse gases and about three-quarters of the total anthropogenic emissions of CH4 and N2O. Considering their contribution to global emissions, it is important to understand their future trends in order to anticipate and mitigate climate change. This paper reviews published scenarios of major categories of these emissions with the aim to provide background information for the development of new scenarios. These categories include CO2 from deforestation, CH4 from rice cultivation, CH4 from enteric fermentation of cattle, and N2O fertilizer application. Base year estimates of all these categories varied greatly from reference to reference, and hence emissions of all scenarios were normalized relative to their 1990 value before being compared to one another. The range of published scenarios of CO2 emissions from deforestation is widest around the middle of the 21(st) century and then all scenarios converge to low values towards 2100. By contrast, the different scenarios of CH4 and N2O diverge with time, showing their widest range in 2100. Global emissions of CH4 from rice cultivation vary by a factor of three in 2100 and N2O from fertilized soils by a factor of 2.3. Emissions of CH4 from enteric fermentation of animals have the smallest range (factor of 2.0). The typical long-range trends of land-use emission scenarios vary greatly from region to region - they stabilize in industrialized regions after a few decades, but tend to stabilize later in developing regions or continue to grow throughout the 21(st) century. To improve the realism of the estimates of future trends of land-use emissions, it is especially important to improve the estimation of the future extent of agricultural land and the rate of deforestation, while taking into account significant driving forces such as the demand for agricultural commodities and crop yields.
Author Keywords: Carbon dioxide emissions; Climate change; Climate change mitigation; Emission; Greenhouse gas emissions; Land-use emissions; Methane emissions; Nitrous oxide emissions; Scenarios
Index Keywords: air pollution; ammonia; carbon dioxide; environmental impact assessment; environmental monitoring; fermentation; nitrous oxide; carbon emission; climate change; greenhouse gas; land use

Authors: Al-Dabbas M.A.F.
Title: Reduction of methane emissions and utilization of municipal waste for energy in Amman
Affiliations: Renewable Energy Department, Min. of Energy and Mineral Resources, P.O. Box 140027, Amman, Jordan
Authors with affiliations: Al-Dabbas, M.A.F., Renewable Energy Department, Min. of Energy and Mineral Resources, P.O. Box 140027, Amman, Jordan
Abstract: The goal of the project is to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases in Jordan by substituting fossil fuels with bioenergy methane gas and electricity produced from anaerobic digestion of industrial and municipal waste in Amman. Additional greenhouse gas reduction will be achieved by reducing the uncontrolled release of methane from improperly disposed organic waste in a large landfill. The project's main activities include a combination of a landfill operation and a biogas plant. The proposed plant will be able to produce 1 MW of electricity based on methane from the landfill and the biogas plant. The project combines methane emission reduction and thus greenhouse gas reduction with production of electricity, thus helping to reduce burden of energy on the Jordan's economy.
Index Keywords: Municipal wastes; biogas; energy production; landfill; methane; waste gas; waste utilization; Biogas; Electric power plants; Greenhouse effect; Land fill; Methane; Solid wastes; Waste utilization; Industrial emissions; alternative energy; biomass power; electricity generation; emissions control; greehouse gas; greenhouse gas; methane; municipal solid waste; Jordan's; Jordan, Amman

Suzuki, T., RIKEN, 2-1 Hirosawa, Wako, Saitama 351-01, Japan; Tengblad, O., Instituto Estructura de la Materia, CSIC, E-28006 Madrid, Spain; Zhukov, M.V., Fysiska Institutionen, Chalmers Tekniska Hogskola/G., S-412 96 Göteborg, Sweden
Abstract: Momentum distributions and invariant mass spectra from the breakup of 6He ions with an energy of 240 MeV/u interacting with a carbon target have been studied. The data were used to extract information about the reaction mechanism which is influenced by the structure of 6He. It is found that the dominant reaction mechanism is a two-step process: knock out of one neutron followed by the decay of the 5He resonance. The shape of the (α + n) two-body invariant mass spectrum is interpreted as mainly reflecting the 5He ground state which is a Jπ= 3/2- resonance. However, no evidence for correlations between α particles and neutrons is observed in the momentum widths of the distributions. It is demonstrated that a combined analysis of the two-body invariant mass spectrum and an appropriate correlation function may be used to determine the properties of the intermediate resonance. © 1998 Elsevier Science B.V.
Author Keywords: 5He; 6He; Breakup reactions; Exotic nuclei; Fragmentation mechanism; Halo nuclei; Invariant mass spectra; Momentum distributions; Secondary radioactive beams

Authors: Allard Douglas W., Patton Kathy, Murphy Tom
Title: Role of innovative technologies in air pollution control strategies
Source title: Proceedings of the Air & Waste Management Association's Annual Meeting & Exhibition
Affiliations: Santa Barbara County Air Pollution, Control District (APCD), United States
Authors with affiliations: Allard, Douglas W., Santa Barbara County Air Pollution, Control District (APCD), United States; Patton, Kathy, Santa Barbara County Air Pollution, Control District (APCD), United States; Murphy, Tom, Santa Barbara County Air Pollution, Control District (APCD), United States
Abstract: The Innovative Technologies Program of the Santa Barbara County Air Pollution Control District implements alternatives to traditional 'command and control' regulatory strategies to reduce air pollution. The program's objectives are to help the county attain federal and state clean air standards for ozone, to work cooperatively with businesses to help them achieve compliance, to jump-start availability of some technologies, to retain local businesses, and to create new business opportunities. This article describes the development and funding of the program, provides project examples, outlines the program's contribution to an overall emission reduction strategy, and discusses implications for future attainment strategies.
Index Keywords: Innovative technologies; Regulatory strategies; Project management; Regulatory compliance; Research and development management; Standards; Strategic planning; Technology transfer; Air pollution control

Authors: Allard D.W., Patton K., Murphy T.
Title: The role of innovative technologies in air pollution control strategies
Source title: EM: Air and Waste Management Association's Magazine for Environmental Managers
Affiliations: S. Barbara Co. Air Poll. Contr. D., Santa Barbara, CA, United States; S. Barbara Co. Air Poll. Contr. D., United States; AeroVironment, Monrovia, CA, United States; California Air Poll. Contr. O., United States; APCD's Technol. Environ. Assess. D.; Innovative Technologies Program
Authors with affiliations: Allard, D.W., S. Barbara Co. Air Poll. Contr. D., Santa Barbara, CA, United States, S. Barbara Co. Air Poll. Contr. D., United States, AeroVironment, Monrovia, CA, United States, California Air Poll. Contr. O., United States; Patton, K., S. Barbara Co. Air Poll. Contr. D., Santa Barbara, CA, United States, S. Barbara Co. Air Poll. Contr. D., United States, APCD's Technol. Environ. Assess. D.; Murphy, T., S. Barbara Co. Air Poll. Contr. D., Santa Barbara, CA, United States, S. Barbara Co. Air Poll. Contr. D., United States, Innovative Technologies Program
Abstract: The Innovative Technologies Program of the Santa Barbara County Air Pollution Control District implements alternatives to traditional "command-and-control" regulatory strategies to reduce air pollution. Winner of the Presidential Award for Sustainable Development and the California Governor's Award for Economic and Environmental Leadership, the program has reduced air pollution, particularly in unregulated and under-regulated sectors, generated new jobs and businesses, and helped convert defense contractors to high-technology manufacturing. More than 60 agencies, manufacturers, support organizations, and users have participated; more than $22 million in projects have been funded. The program was started in 1988 with $7 million from oil companies constructing multi-billion dollar local production facilities. The money was earmarked for innovative low-emissions technology projects to reduce the substantial air quality impacts caused by construction of those facilities. For every dollar of original funding, the program has secured two to five dollars from other participants, including federal, state, and local government agencies, utilities, and businesses. The program's objectives are to help the county attain federal and state clean air standards for ozone, to work cooperatively with businesses to help them achieve compliance, to jump-start availability of certain technologies, to retain local businesses, and to create new business oppurtunities. As clean air technologies have matured, the program's focus has made the transition from promotion of early demonstrations of new technologies to new areas. Examples include projects that promote cleaner technologies in marine, agricultural, and transportation applications. This article describes the development and funding of the program, provides project examples, outlines the program's contribution to an overall emission reduction strategy, and discusses implications for future attainment strategies.

Authors: Allen G.C., Hallam K.R.
Title: Carbon deposition from a γ-irradiated CO2/CO/CH4/C2H6 gas mixture on magnetite Fe3O4
Affiliations: University of Bristol, Interface Analysis Centre, 121 St. Michael's Hill, Bristol BS2 8BS, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Allen, G.C., University of Bristol, Interface Analysis Centre, 121 St. Michael's Hill, Bristol BS2 8BS, United Kingdom; Hallam, K.R., University of Bristol, Interface Analysis Centre, 121 St. Michael's Hill, Bristol BS2 8BS, United Kingdom
Abstract: Previous studies have indicated that carbon is deposited on spinel-type oxides containing manganese, iron, nickel and chromium manganese oxides and uranium oxides, especially where rapid electron exchange is possible in mixed valence compounds. In this investigation, characterised magnetite, Fe3O4, surfaces have been subjected to γ-irradiation under conditions of temperature, pressure and atmosphere similar to those experienced in reactor with the aim of furthering our understanding of the catalytic processes involved in deposit initiation and growth. Although it was not possible to produce large (111) Fe3O4 planes, enhanced carbon deposition was observed on small (111) regions showing the enhanced catalytic effect of these planes for carbon deposition out of the gas phase. © 1998 Elsevier Science B.V.
Index Keywords: Carbon; Carbon dioxide; Crystal structure; Ethane; Gamma rays; Methane; Vapor deposition; Carbon deposition; Gamma irradiation; Gas mixtures; Magnetite

Authors: Almarzouki F., El-Hennawy A., Al-Ghamdi S., Al-Ameer S.S.
Title: A new MOSFET IC laser-driver with on-chip thermal and optical stabilization
Source title: Arab Gulf Journal of Scientific Research
Affiliations: Faculty of Science, Physics Department, King Abdulaziz University, P.O. Box 9028, Jeddah 21413, Saudi Arabia
Authors with affiliations: Almarzouki, F., Faculty of Science, Physics Department, King Abdulaziz University, P.O. Box 9028, Jeddah 21413, Saudi Arabia; El-Hennawy, A., Faculty of Science, Physics Department, King Abdulaziz University, P.O. Box 9028, Jeddah 21413, Saudi Arabia; Al-Ghamdi, S., Faculty of Science, Physics Department, King Abdulaziz University, P.O. Box 9028, Jeddah 21413, Saudi Arabia; Al-Ameer, S.S., Faculty of Science, Physics Department, King Abdulaziz University, P.O. Box 9028, Jeddah 21413, Saudi Arabia
Abstract: This paper presents a new more advantageous configuration for the laser diode that is used as the principle light source in optical fiber communications and a range of other applications. Most of the common drawbacks have been eradicated through the new design which is integrated through the well known floating gate MOSFET technology. Advantages including improved thermal and optical stabilization and easy direct modulation are realized from a new on-chip laser driver. Besides, the technique guarantees compensation for device leakage and device to device tolerances. The resulting device is cheaper and easy to construct. The voltage control provides better output power modulation and improve linearity for high output power levels. The threshold current required to stimulate emission is also reduced to ≃ 103 A/cm2 at 300 K with an active region thickness of ≃ 0.5 μm. In fact the proposed design provides a thinner well defined active region (0.3 μm) which also acts as an optical cavity resonator, besides satisfying the conditions for the confinement of charged carriers and optical fields.

Authors: Alonso C.D.
Title: The air pollution driving ban scheme in the Sao Paulo Metropolitan Region
Affiliations: CETESB, Brazil; Sec. de Estado do Meio Ambiente, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Alonso, C.D., CETESB, Brazil, Sec. de Estado do Meio Ambiente, Brazil
Abstract: In the Sao Paulo Metropolitan Region (SPMR), the largest and most industrialized urban center in South America, air pollution often reaches high concentrations. Motor vehicles are by far the largest source of air pollutants in the SPMR, contributing with 98% CO, 97% hydrocarbons (HC), 95% NOx, 61% SOx, and 40% particulate matter (PM10). Although various air pollution control measures have been implemented over the years, such as complete gasoline lead phase-out, sulfur reduction in diesel fuel and gasoline, 22% ethanol blend with gasoline, use of neat ethanol as automotive fuel, increase of compressed natural gas use, ~ 90% reduction of exhaust and evaporative emissions from new vehicles, and road enforcement of diesel smoke emissions, fleet growth and increasing vehicle use have been the balancing part of the gains obtained by these measures. Different ″No-drive day″ schemes, based on air pollution related traffic reduction requirements, were implemented in 1995, 1996, and 1997 in SPMR to reduce emissions of CO, PM10, NOx, SOx, and HC in the atmosphere and to lessen traffic congestion. Experiences encountered in the implementation of the schemes are presented.

Authors: Alonso-Herrero A., Simpson C., Ward M.J., Wilson A.S.
Title: A near-infrared imaging study of seyfert galaxies with extended emission-line regions
Affiliations: Steward Observatory, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Space Telescope Science Institute, 3700 San Martin Drive, Baltimore, MD 21218, United States; Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Leicester, Leicester LE1 7RH, United Kingdom; Astronomy Department, University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20742, United States; Jet Propulsion Laboratory, 4800 Oak Grove Drive, Pasadena, CA 91109, United States
Authors with affiliations: Alonso-Herrero, A., Steward Observatory, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States, Space Telescope Science Institute, 3700 San Martin Drive, Baltimore, MD 21218, United States; Simpson, C., Space Telescope Science Institute, 3700 San Martin Drive, Baltimore, MD 21218, United States; Ward, M.J., Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Leicester, Leicester LE1 7RH, United Kingdom, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, 4800 Oak Grove Drive, Pasadena, CA 91109, United States; Wilson, A.S., Astronomy Department, University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20742, United States
Abstract: We present a near-infrared J-, H-, K-, and L′-band (1.25-3.80 μm) imaging study of a sample of Seyfert galaxies, including some of the best studied examples of those with extended emission-line regions (EELRs). The observed near-IR nuclear colors are consistent with a mixture of emissions from an old stellar population and unreddened hot dust. However, if the hot dust is located in the inner part of the dusty torus invoked in unified schemes, the dust emission should suffer substantial reddening. We show that the near-IR nuclear colors may also be reproduced with a combination of emission from unreddened starlight and hot (T = 1200 K) dust reddened by AV ≈ 5-30 mag. All of the galaxies exhibit an unresolved nuclear source at L. The circumnuclear colors (in a 0.5-1.0 kpc annulus) are similar to those of normal spiral galaxies in most cases, although some galaxies exhibit extended emission at L′, presumably from hot dust, which causes the circumnuclear K - L′. colors to be redder than for normal galaxies. We argue that the circumnuclear hot dust in NGC 1068 and NGC 4151 is probably heated by young stars. A detailed study of the morphologies of the central and circumnuclear regions of the galaxies in our sample is presented. We have constructed smooth models of the old stellar population by fitting elliptical isophotes to the J- and K-band images. The model-divided images are examined for the presence of isophotal deviations from elliptical symmetry, such as internal bars, spiral arms, etc., and compared with the structures seen in optical emission-line images, to study the relative orientations of bars, the EELRs, the nuclear radio emission, and the host galaxy. We find stellar bars in NGC 1068 and NGC 4253 whose orientations are consistent with those of their EELRs and evidence for double bars (or "bars within bars") in Mrk 573, NGC 3081, and NGC 3393. Only in NGC 2110 and NGC 4151 do we find no significant isophotal deviations from elliptical symmetry. Finally, there is an alignment on small scales between the near-IR continuum and the line emission in four galaxies, NGC 1068, NGC 2110, NGC 3081, and NGC 4253. These results seem to suggest that there is not a unique explanation for the orientation of the EELRs seen in Seyfert galaxies. In some cases, the EELRs could represent gas aligned with the nuclear stellar bars, whereas in others, they are more likely to be related to gas escaping along the minor axis of the galaxies. © 1998. The American Astronomical Society. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Galaxies: active; Galaxies: nuclei; Galaxies: photometry; Galaxies: Seyfert; Galaxies: stellar content; Infrared: galaxies

Authors: Al-Shorepy S.A., Notter D.R.
Title: Genetic parameters for lamb birth weight in spring and autumn lambing
Affiliations: Dept. of Animal and Poultry Sciences, Virginia Polytech. Inst. and Stt. U., Blacksburg, VA 24061-0306, United States; Faculty of Agriculture, Sana'a University, Sana'a, Yemen
Authors with affiliations: Al-Shorepy, S.A., Dept. of Animal and Poultry Sciences, Virginia Polytech. Inst. and Stt. U., Blacksburg, VA 24061-0306, United States, Faculty of Agriculture, Sana'a University, Sana'a, Yemen; Notter, D.R., Dept. of Animal and Poultry Sciences, Virginia Polytech. Inst. and Stt. U., Blacksburg, VA 24061-0306, United States
Abstract: Genetic parameters for birth weight were estimated for two sets of spring-born and one set of autumn-born lambs of the same breed composition and genetic origin using a model that included random additive, additive maternal, permanent environmental maternal, litter and residual effects. Litter effects were significant for all data sets, indicating that within-year effects of common environment and (or) non-additive genotype were important for birth weight and should be included in genetic evaluation programmes. Estimates of variance components for autumn-born lambs differed significantly from those obtained from spring-born lambs or from the combined data. In contrast, estimates obtained for the two sets of spring-born lambs did not differ from those obtained when data on all spring-born lambs were pooled. The estimate of h2 for birth weight in spring-born lambs was over twice as large as that obtained for autumn-born lambs (0·26 v. 0·12). In contrast, the across-year repeatability of ewe effects was much larger in autumn lambs (0·41 v. 0·26) as was the full-sib littermate correlation (0·73 v. 0·49). Mean birth weights were also 0·4 to 0·6 kg less in autumn lambs. These results suggest that negative effects on birth weight that have been reported for lambs gestated during summer in equatorial and subtropical regions are also manifested (albeit at reduced levels) in less extreme climates (in this case, 37°, 15′ N latitude and 654 m elevation) and that maternal variation exists in the ability of the ewe to maintain adequate lamb birth weights in autumn lambing systems.
Author Keywords: Birth weight; Genetic parameters; Seasonal variation; Sheep

Authors: Al-Suwaidi A.S., Aziz S.K.
Title: Regional basin modelling: An approach to understand shelfal carbonate reservoirs of the Oxfordian and Kimmeridgian in offshore Abu Dhabi
Source title: Society of Petroleum Engineers - Abu Dhabi International Petroleum Exhibition and Conference 1998, ADIPEC 1998
Affiliations: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (ADNOC), United Arab Emirates
Authors with affiliations: Al-Suwaidi, A.S., Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (ADNOC), United Arab Emirates; Aziz, S.K., Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (ADNOC), United Arab Emirates
Abstract: Exploration activities in Abu Dhabi have traditionally been focused on the reservoir zones of the lower Cretaceous Thamama Croup and the Jurassic Arab and Araej Formations. The carbonate reservoirs developed along the eastern flank of the Oxfordian - Kimmeridgian intra-shelf depression in offshore Abu Dhabi received less attention. until recently when commercial oil accumulations in structural traps were discovered. A multidisciplinary study using sequence stratigraphic approach resulted in clarifying the geometry and the chronostratigraphic relationships of the identified sequences. The study included regional seismic data, litho-biofacies studies, geochemical analysis, strontium isotope age dating and well logs from over 50 wells. After the deposition of the Callovian Upper Araej member, a differentiated carbonate platform was initiated in early Oxfordian in offshore and western onshore Abu Dhabi where tectonic subsidence coupled with sea level fluctuation controlled the geometry, deposition and the distribution of variable lithofacies that ranged from organic rich limemudstones in the depressed area to porous and permeable bioclastic packstones. grainstones and dolomites in the shallow waters along the eastern flank of the intrashelf basin. Detailed study resulted in identifying four 3rd-order sequences in the Oxfordian to Middle Kimmeridgian stages in the offshore area. Sequence-1 is entirely Oxfordian and is deposited during transgressive and highstand periods dominated by aggrading and prograding geometries. Sequence II is Lower Kimmeridgian and represented by a well-defined lowstand system tract followed by short-lived transgressive and highstand system tracts. Sequence III is mainly deposited during a lowstand period capped with a shelf margin wedge system tract. Finally, Sequence IV was deposited entirely during transgressive and highstand periods on an undifferentiated platform with minor depression in the western area. Two type I sequence boundaries have been interpreted at the top of Sequences I and II in the shelfal area. The best reservoir developments occur in the bioclastic packstone and grainstone facies deposited during the highstand periods below the Sequences I and II boundaries where the reservoir units are characterized by porosities of < 20% but with very high permeabilities reaching a few Darcys. The basinal facies of Sequence I exhibits the best source potential in the intrashelf basin, whereas the remaining sequences show marginal source rock richness. © 1998. Society of Petroleum Engineers.
Index Keywords: Analytical geochemistry; Carbonation; Deposition; Gasoline; Geometry; Lime; Offshore oil well production; Petroleum geology; Petroleum reservoirs; Sea level; Seismology; Stratigraphy; Well logging; Carbonate platforms; Carbonate reservoir; Geochemical analysis; Highstand systems; Lowstand system tracts; Sea-level fluctuations; Strontium isotopes; Type I sequence boundaries; Offshore oil wells

Authors: Alvaro M., Fornés V., García S., García H., Scaiano J.C.
Title: Intrazeolite photochemistry. 20. Characterization of highly luminescent europium complexes inside zeolites
Affiliations: Inst. de Tecn. Química, Departamento de Química, Univ. Politécnica de Valencia, Apartado 22012, 46071 Valencia, Spain; Department of Chemistry, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, Ont. K1N 6N5, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Alvaro, M., Inst. de Tecn. Química, Departamento de Química, Univ. Politécnica de Valencia, Apartado 22012, 46071 Valencia, Spain; Fornés, V., Inst. de Tecn. Química, Departamento de Química, Univ. Politécnica de Valencia, Apartado 22012, 46071 Valencia, Spain; García, S., Inst. de Tecn. Química, Departamento de Química, Univ. Politécnica de Valencia, Apartado 22012, 46071 Valencia, Spain; García, H., Inst. de Tecn. Química, Departamento de Química, Univ. Politécnica de Valencia, Apartado 22012, 46071 Valencia, Spain; Scaiano, J.C., Department of Chemistry, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, Ont. K1N 6N5, Canada
Abstract: Four organometallic complexes of Eu3+ with 2,2′-bipyridine (bipy), benzoyltrifluoroacetone (btfa), 1,10-phenanthroline (phen), and dipicolinic acid (dpic) have been prepared in Y, mordenite, and ZSM-5 zeolites by adsorbing the ligand into Eu3+-doped zeolites. Different samples were obtained varying the Eu3+ content and the Eu3+:ligand ratio. Formation of the complexes and their stoichiometry have been assessed by elemental chemical analysis (combustion and atomic absorption) and thermogravimetry-differential scanning calorimetry as well as IR and diffuse reflectance (DR) spectroscopies. The distinctive feature of DR spectra of the solids is the presence of a band of medium intensity in the 500 nm region that is absent for the same complexes in solution. All the samples, including those that do not contain any organic ligand, exhibit room-temperature emission upon laser excitation, although luminescence intensity notably increases upon complexation. The emission lifetimes are in the millisecond time scale and do not follow simple first-order kinetics. Concerning the emission decay, the following observations were made: (i) the complex luminescence is much longer lived inside the zeolites than in solution; (ii) the emission lifetime follows the order dpic > phen > bipy > bfta; (iii) lifetime increases with the amount of the ligand incorporated; (iv) the decays are more rapid as the Eu3+ content of the zeolite increases; and (v) emission becomes longer lived in the older ZSM-5 > mordenite > Y. These facts have been rationalized as the result of an increase in the conformational rigidity experienced by the complex that impedes alternative nonemissive deactivation pathways in zeolite media. Dehydration of the solids and subsequent D2O rehydration does not alter the decay of the uncomplexed Eu3+-Y samples but increases the lifetime of the Eu-btfa complex inside Y zeolite by a factor of 2. This is indicative that emitting Eu3+ are not solvated (probably located inside the sodalite cages and hexagonal prisms), while the Eu-btfa complex is coordinated with a single H2O molecule.

Authors: Alves L.C., Reis M.A., Freitas M.C.
Title: Air particulate matter characterisation of a rural area in Portugal
Source title: Nuclear Instruments and Methods in Physics Research, Section B: Beam Interactions with Materials and Atoms
Affiliations: Nuclear and Technological Institute, E.N.10, Physics Department, 2686 Sacavém Codex, Portugal; Nuclear and Technological Institute, E.N.10, Chemistry Department, 2686 Sacavém Codex, Portugal
Authors with affiliations: Alves, L.C., Nuclear and Technological Institute, E.N.10, Physics Department, 2686 Sacavém Codex, Portugal; Reis, M.A., Nuclear and Technological Institute, E.N.10, Physics Department, 2686 Sacavém Codex, Portugal; Freitas, M.C., Nuclear and Technological Institute, E.N.10, Chemistry Department, 2686 Sacavém Codex, Portugal
Abstract: An aerosol monitoring of a rural and an urban area was accomplished in the frame of an international project promoted by the IAEA. The Gent PM10 air sampler equipped with Norwegian Institute for Air Research (NILU) stacked filter units (SFU) was used for air particulate matter sampling. Filter loads were measured by gravimetry and elemental concentration analysis carried out with both PIXE and INAA techniques. In this work we report the results obtained in a rural area located at 30 km east of Oporto, near a coal fired power plant. The samples were collected from September 1995 to August 1996 on a twice a week basis. The use of complementary analytical techniques allowed to determine concentrations for 23 elements. Time variations for both total particulate mass and elemental concentrations are presented. Enrichment factors were calculated for the fine (PM < 2 μm) and the coarse (10 > PM > 2 μm) fractions. Principal Components Analysis was applied to infer particulate mass emission sources. Another Gent air sampler was installed at the same sampling site but under different working conditions. Time averages obtained with the two systems are also compared. The results obtained with the two collectors operating under different conditions suggest that the statistical distribution of pollutants can be accounted by taking the average of a week and therefore a weekly monitoring of airborne particulate matter is proposed. A factor related to the coal fired power plant emissions has been identified. Since the power plant is going to be converted from coal to natural gas combustion, the results now obtained are important for a future comparison. © 1998 Elsevier Science B.V.
Index Keywords: Air filters; Atmospheric aerosols; Combustion; Fossil fuel power plants; Industrial emissions; Particulate emissions; Rural areas; Sampling; Statistical methods; Principal component analysis; Proton induced X ray emission; Air pollution

Authors: Alzérreca-Angelo H., Schupp E.W., Kitchen S.G.
Title: Sheep grazing and plant cover dynamics of a shadscale community
Affiliations: Casilla 13697, La Paz, Bolivia; Dept. Rangeland Rsrc. the Ecol. Ctr., Utah State University, Logan, UT 84322-5230, United States; U.S.D.A. Forest Service, Intermountain Research Station, Shrub Sciences Laboratory, Provo, UT 84606, United States; Department of Rangeland Resources, Utah State University
Authors with affiliations: Alzérreca-Angelo, H., Casilla 13697, La Paz, Bolivia, Department of Rangeland Resources, Utah State University; Schupp, E.W., Dept. Rangeland Rsrc. the Ecol. Ctr., Utah State University, Logan, UT 84322-5230, United States; Kitchen, S.G., U.S.D.A. Forest Service, Intermountain Research Station, Shrub Sciences Laboratory, Provo, UT 84606, United States
Abstract: Despite extensive coverage and long-term use, the extent to which shadscale [Atriplex confertifolia (Torr. and Frem.) Wats.] community dynamics are driven by grazing rather than by climate and inherent plant characteristics is unresolved. We analyze a 59-year data set from the Desert Experimental Range, southwester Utah, with the objective of discriminating between grazing and non-grazing effects on cover dynamics. Canopy cover of (5 x 20 ft) 9.3 m2 plots were estimated in 1935, 1958, 1969, 197, and 1994. Treatments were time (5 dates), grazing (ungrazed versus grazed), and season (spring versus winter). Time was significant; total cover initially increased following release from uncontrolled grazing and improvement of climate (1935-58, P < 0.001), remained unchanged over the following dry interval (1958-69, P = 1.000), increased over a drier interval (1969-75, P < 0.001), and then decreased dramatically over the final wet period (1975-94, P < 0.001). Grazing was also significant (P < 0.001), but cover of ungrazed plots exceeded that of grazed plots only in 1975 and 1994 (P ≤ 0.033). The 6 dominant species showed varying responses to grazing and time, with some responding primarily to grazing (e.g., budsage, Artemisia spinescens D.C. Eaton in Wats.) and others responding primarily to time (climate, longevity, etc., e.g., Indian ricegrass, Oryzopsis hymenoides R. and S.). Similarly, seasonal effects were not universal. Shrub cover initially increased and then declined dramatically while grass cover monotonically increased. Results suggest that release from uncontrolled grazing coupled with improving climatic conditions were responsible for initial recovery of the community, but that over time, climate and inherent plant traits (e.g., longevity, establishment ecology, etc.) became relatively more important. For total cover and for many individual species, continued grazing affected the rate more than the direction of vegetation change.
Author Keywords: Artemisia spinescens; Atriplex confertifolia; Ceratoides lanata; Climate; Hilaria jamesii; Oryzopsis hymenoides; Sporobolus cryptandrus; Vegetation dynamics

Authors: Anderberg S.
Title: Industrial metabolism and the linkages between economics, ethics and the environment
Affiliations: IND Project, IIASA, Laxenburg, Austria; Dept. of Social and Economic Geogr., Lund University, Lund, Sweden; Institute of Geography, University of Copenhagen, Copenhagen, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Anderberg, S., IND Project, IIASA, Laxenburg, Austria, Dept. of Social and Economic Geogr., Lund University, Lund, Sweden, Institute of Geography, University of Copenhagen, Copenhagen, Denmark
Abstract: With industrialization, the material flows in the world have grown enormously, expanded geographically and become more open and complex. Traditionally, the emissions have been strongly connected to earlier steps in the material flows (extraction and raw-materials intensive industry), but during the last few decades, the emissions from industrial pointsources have decreased radically in the Western industrialized world. The result of the industrial 'cleanup' is a shift towards the latter steps of the societal material flows; the relative importance of consumption emissions has increased. As indicated in studies of the Rhine Basin, important prerequisites for this development have been increasing environmental awareness and public opinion, putting pressure on legislators, authorities and companies and a dynamic industrial development with structural changes, that have permitted investments in modern technology and emissions control. Despite the often radical emission reductions, problems with acidification, eutrophication, diffusion of persistent organic chemicals and climate change still persist on a regional and global level. During the last decade, there has been an increasing emphasis on the international and global environmental problems. The materials flow perspective has experienced a major breakthrough. Waste minimization, recycling, life-cycle analysis and environmental auditing have become major themes in most European countries and have also started to influence industry. The importance of the consumer and his attitudes and actions, as well as the relationship between trade and environment are often emphasized in this context. The industrial metabolism approach needs further development to be able to assist in meeting the modern challenges of environmental management. To sum up flows of a few elements or products in a limited region is not sufficient. It is necessary to develop the analysis of the context of the flows, include industrial, economic and geographical change in the analysis and more actively seek connection to political and industrial decision-making and human behavior and attitudes. The time-geographical Process Landscape launched by Torsten Hagerstrand could be an important source of inspiration in this context.
Author Keywords: Industrial metabolism; Material flows; Research challenges; The process landscape; The Rhine
Index Keywords: emissions control; environmental economics; environmental ethics; industrialisation; Europe, Rhine Basin

Authors: Anderson Larry G., Wilkes Edward B.
Title: Effects of oxygenated fuels use on I/M240 emissions test results in Colorado
Source title: Proceedings of the Air & Waste Management Association's Annual Meeting & Exhibition
Affiliations: Univ of Colorado at Denver, Denver, United States
Authors with affiliations: Anderson, Larry G., Univ of Colorado at Denver, Denver, United States; Wilkes, Edward B., Univ of Colorado at Denver, Denver, United States
Abstract: The effects of oxygenated fuels use on the emissions from motor vehicles is assessed using IM240 emissions data collected in the Denver metropolitan area during 1995 and 1996. The results of the 1996 test year are very different from the 1995 results. The benefits of oxygenated fuels on the reduction of CO emissions from the 1995 IM240 data are consistent with the results of ambient data analysis reported previously, but much lower than MOBILE 5A predictions. Due to some disturbing aspects of the study, additional studies of the effects of reformulated gasoline on NOx emissions are necessary.
Index Keywords: Carbon monoxide; Fuels; Gasoline; Nitrogen oxides; Vehicles; Motor vehicles; Oxygenated fuels; Gas emissions

Authors: Andreani-Aksoyoglu S., Keller J.
Title: Short-term impacts of air pollutants in Switzerland: Model evaluations and preliminary scenario calculations for selected Swiss energy systems
Source title: International Conference on Air Pollution - Proceedings
Affiliations: Paul Scherrer Inst, Villigen, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Andreani-Aksoyoglu, S., Paul Scherrer Inst, Villigen, Switzerland; Keller, J., Paul Scherrer Inst, Villigen, Switzerland
Abstract: In the frame of the comprehensive assessment of Swiss energy systems, air quality model simulations were performed using a 3-dimensional model (Urban Airshed Model, UAM). The aim of the study is to understand the chemical and meteorological processes so that simulations can be performed for investigating the impacts of pollutants in Switzerland for the present situation as well as for the future energy systems. As a first step, the model performance was evaluated on the basis of air quality simulations of a 3-day period in July 1993 in Switzerland. The areas where the production of photochemical pollutants are sensitive to NOx and VOC emissions were derived. The location of these areas were found to depend on the prevailing wind regimes. After the evaluation of the model performance, some scenario calculations were performed as follows: Base Case : simulations with the projected emissions for the year 2030, Scenario 1) all nuclear power plants were replaced by oil-driven combined cycle plants, Scenarios 2-4) traffic emissions were reduced in whole Switzerland as well as in the cities and on the highways separately. Changes in the pollutant concentrations and depositions, and the possible short-term impacts are discussed on the basis of exceedences of critical levels for plants and limits given to protect the public health. Calculations of the long-term impacts of pollutants on ecosystems under all typical meteorological conditions encountered over the whole year are in progress.
Index Keywords: Air quality; Atmospheric chemistry; Computational methods; Computer simulation; Exhaust gases; Gas emissions; Industrial emissions; Meteorology; Nitrogen oxides; Photochemical reactions; Volatile organic compounds; Wind; Software package UAM; Air pollution

Authors: Andrew Gray H., Cass G.R.
Title: Source contributions to atmospheric fine carbon particle concentrations
Affiliations: Environ. Eng. Science Department, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA 91125, United States
Authors with affiliations: Andrew Gray, H., Environ. Eng. Science Department, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA 91125, United States; Cass, G.R., Environ. Eng. Science Department, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA 91125, United States
Abstract: A Lagrangian particle-in-cell air quality model has been developed that facilitates the study of source contributions to atmospheric fine elemental carbon and fine primary total carbon particle concentrations. Model performance was tested using spatially and temporally resolved emissions and air quality data gathered for this purpose in the Los Angeles area for the year 1982. It was shown that black elemental carbon (EC) particle concentrations in that city were dominated by emissions from diesel engines including both on-highway and off-highway applications. Fine primary total carbon particle concentrations (TC = EC+organic carbon) resulted from the accumulation of small increments from a great variety of emission source types including both gasoline and diesel powered highway vehicles, stationary source fuel oil and gas combustion, industrial processes, paved road dust, fireplaces, cigarettes and food cooking (e.g. charbroilers). Strategies for black elemental carbon particle concentration control will of necessity need to focus on diesel engines, while controls directed at total carbon particle concentrations will have to be diversified over a great many source types.A Lagrangian particle-in-cell air quality model has been developed that facilitates the study of source contributions to atmospheric fine elemental carbon and fine primary total carbon particle concentrations. Model performance was tested using spatially and temporally resolved emissions and air quality data gathered for this purpose in the Los Angeles area for the year 1982. It was shown that black elemental carbon (EC) particle concentrations in that city were dominated by emissions from diesel engines including both on-highway and off-highway applications. Fine primary total carbon particle concentrations (TC=EC+organic carbon) resulted from the accumulation of small increments from a great variety of emission source types including both gasoline and diesel powered highway vehicles, stationary source fuel oil and gas combustion, industrial processes, paved road dust, fireplaces, cigarettes and food cooking (e.g. charbroilers). Strategies for black elemental carbon particle concentration control will of necessity need to focus on diesel engines, while controls directed at total carbon particle concentrations will have to be diversified over a great many source types.
